Award.AwardTitle: GOALI/Collaborative Research: Process Development across Alloy Systems for Powder Bed Additive Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative Grant Opportunities for Academic Liaison with Industry (GOALI) project will apply fundamental research to the problem of controlling melt pool dimensions and microstructure for electron beam direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Specifically, it will address how to transfer control methods developed for one material system to another material system in a way that reduces costly and time-consuming experimentation. To accomplish this, this project will develop a first-of-its kind modeling-based process mapping approach for application across different materials used in direct metal powder bed additive manufacturing processes. Process mapping methods will be applied to experiments performed on multiple metal alloys using additive manufacturing equipment available to the investigators.

Direct metal additive manufacturing is of great interest to the aerospace, medical implant, and other industries. It offers the promise of decreased manufacturing cost, substantial reductions in the amount of material used to build a component, and the ability to fabricate structures not realizable by conventional manufacturing methods. Two barriers to widespread use of direct metal additive manufacturing in the aerospace and other industries are (1) the lack of a platform for transferring process knowledge (e.g. how to build shapes) from one metal alloy system to another; and (2) limited knowledge about controlling microstructure and mechanical properties for any alloy system. These barriers lead to expensive, costly experimentation in applying additive manufacturing to new material systems and the inability to certify mechanical strength in fabricated components. This project will overcome both of these barriers through research accomplished by a team that includes academic investigators from three universities (North Carolina State, Carnegie Mellon and Wright State) and a collaborator from the aerospace industry currently working to integrate direct metal additive manufacturing into component production (Pratt & Whitney).

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metal additive manufacturing (AM) has a tremendous potential to address many unmet challenges from industry. Electron Beam Melting (EBM) is one major powder bed metal AM process that utilizes an electron beam as the energy source to scan and melt selected regions for each layer and manufactures the component in a layer-by-layer fashion. Due to its inherent nature of freeform fabrication, EBM is capable of manufacturing components with much more complex designs while reducing setup cost and turnover time. Thanks to such unparalleled advantages, EBM is now on the verge for wide adoption in various industry sectors as a means of production.

However, only a few materials are fully developed for EBM, which is becoming a major obstacle to hinder the adoption progress of this technology. New material development for EBM is no different than that for any other manufacturing processes, which mainly relies on extensive experimentations. Such a process is expensive and time consuming, which can often take several years for an experienced process engineer to fully optimize key parameters with regard to desired as-built part properties.  

This project proposed a new material development approach for the EBM process based on a finite element simulation model, which can greatly reduce the experimental cost and speed up the development process for new alloy systems. This novel simulation guided material development process starts with some quick and simple experiments in the EBM system by varying two key process parameters, namely electron beam power and scanning velocity (P-V). The results serve as initial inputs into the model for calibration to certain alloy system. Next, the calibrated simulation model generates power and velocity based on melt pool properties (microstructures and morphologies) that are desired in real manufacturing scenario. Finally, another set of simple and quick experiments is carried out using the P-V model generated. The experimental results are compared with model predicted melt pool properties to validate model fidelity. As to this simulation model, it can be easily transferred among different alloy systems by calibrating initial model parameters for specific material in its first and second steps. In this project, we started with a model for Ti6Al4V (a titanium based light alloy commonly used for aerospace and biomedical applications) and successfully transferred it for Inconel 718 and 625 (2 nickel based super alloys widely used for high temperature aerospace applications).

Such a simulation based approach for EBM dramatically expedites the material development process and reducing cost, thus promoting the adoption of EBM technology to address growing needs from more industry sectors for various applications with more new materials at lower cost.

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2017
Modified by: Ola L Harrysson
